headline: Swiss Fondue
summary: In search of the best fondue Switzerland has to offer

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Can Anyone Repeat Huckabee's Iowa Magic?
summary: For months, analysts have wondered which Republican candidate might reassemble the coalition that former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee rode to victory in the 2008 Iowa caucuses.

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Dec. 30, 2011

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of Dec. 30, 2011

headline: Stoudemire Is Hurting, and So Are the Knicks
summary: The Knicks' slow start could be exacerbated by Amar'e Stoudemire's bad ankle. Plus, Rex Ryan gives Brian Schottenheimer a vote of confidence, and the Rangers jettison Sean Avery again.

headline: Apple Lead Designer Knighted
summary: Apple Senior Vice President Jonathan Ive has received a knighthood from Queen Elizabeth II for his work in leading the design of some of the company's most innovative products.

headline: Tests Find Infant Formula Not Contaminated
summary: The FDA and the CDC said tests of factory-sealed containers of an infant formula, made by Mead Johnson Nutrition, suspected last week of being tainted, showed no contamination.

headline: Dow Gains 5.5% in 2011; S&P Ends Flat
summary: The S&P 500 closed the year down 0.04 point at 1257.60, its smallest annual move since at least 1970. The Dow industrials closed the year up 5.5% at 12217.56. The Nasdaq Composite closed the year down 1.8%.

headline: Air Force Awards Afghan Plane Contract
summary: The Air Force has awarded a contract to supply a small fleet of attack planes to Afghanistan, following a politically charged contest between rival aircraft manufacturers.

headline: Pipeline Financial Fires Staff of Subsidiary
summary: Trading system operator terminates eight employees of its trading subsidiary, two months after the firm settled allegations that it improperly misled clients about its relationship with the unit.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: G.K. Chesterton on what constitutes smart social reform.

headline: Euro Hits 11-Year Low Against Yen
summary: Europe's debt crisis continued to take a toll on the euro, as it ended 2011 at an 11-year low against the yen and just one cent above the 15-month lows hit earlier this week against the dollar.

headline: Pfizer Vaccine Wins Expanded Approval
summary: Pfizer said its blockbuster pneumococcal vaccine Prevnar 13 won FDA approval for use in adults 50 years and older.

headline: Failed-Bank Tally Falls to 92
summary: U.S bank failures slowed to a trickle at the end of 2011, but that doesn't mean they are coming to an end.

headline: Latin American Markets Close 2011 in Retreat
summary: Major Latin American stock indexes and currencies declined in 2011 as investors shunned conventionally risky assets and exporters amid the euro-zone debt crisis and signs of a slowing global economy.

headline: Photos of the Day: Dec. 30
summary: In today's photos, a U.S. presidential hopeful counts on his aide's support, Russian firefighters battle a blaze on a nuclear submarine, Times Square prepares for a party, and more.

headline: Treasurys: Below 2% for First Time Since '77
summary: Treasury bonds ended this year on a high note, wrapping up the best year since the 2008 global financial crisis and beating U.S. stocks and corporate bonds.

headline: David Rubin Pleads Guilty in Muni-Bond Trial
summary: California municipal-bond broker CDR Financial and its founder plead guilty to criminal charges in the U.S. government's probe into alleged bid-rigging and price-fixing in the municipal finance market.

headline: Letter to Mark Hurd Alleging Harassment
summary: A letter that touched off events leading to Mark Hurd's resignation as Hewlett-Packard Co.'s chief executive describes an "uncomfortable dance that went on almost two years," alleging that his unwanted advances put a female contractor in the difficult position of rejecting her boss while trying to preserve her job.

headline: Gold Ends Year Up 10%
summary: Gold futures climbed Friday, rebounding from a string of losses, to score a gain of 10% on the year. Silver futures also gained for the session, but ended the year with a loss of 9.8%.

headline: Crude Oil Ends Year With 8.2% Gain
summary: Oil futures drifted lower Friday on light holiday volume, with little to guide the market other Light, sweet crude for February delivery shed 82 cents, or 0.8%, to settle at $98.83 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

headline: Financial Briefing Book: Dec. 31
summary: Financial Briefing Book: Dec. 31

headline: Gundlach and TCW Settle Spat
summary: The bond-fund manager and his former employer agreed to end a legal fight stemming from his 2009 dismissal.

headline: LDK Solar, Golfsmith International Holdings: Biggest Price Decliners (LDK, GOLF)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

headline: Program Trading
summary: Program trading in the week ended Dec. 23 amounted to 32.2% of New York Stock Exchange average daily volume of 1.55 billion shares, or 497.8 million program shares traded per day.

headline: Noah Education Holdings, MoSys: Biggest Price Gainers (NED, MOSY)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: JPMorgan Chase, Honda Motor: Money Flow Leaders (JPM, HMC)
summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

headline: Europe's Markets Tumble in 2011
summary: European equities posted modest daily gains, but ended 2011 with heavy yearly losses as the euro zone's sovereign debt crisis took its toll. The Stoxx Europe 600 index lost 11% for the year.

headline: Japan's Year of Industrial-Size Problems
summary: What a tumultuous year for Japanese industrial production. The outlook remains challenging.

headline: BP to End Venture With Rosneft
summary: BP said it will end its 13-year alliance with Russia's Rosneft to explore for oil and gas in Sakhalin, due in part to the challenging economics of the Far East project.

headline: Silvercorp Hires Consultants to Assess Resources
summary: Silvercorp Metals has retained two well-known consulting firms to give more credibility to assessments of its mineral properties, including projects in China.

headline: Asian Shares Draw Curtain to Dismal Year
summary: Japanese and Chinese markets notched gains in the final trading day of the year, but benchmarks in both countries tumbled during 2011.

headline: Libya Port to Resume Oil Exports
summary: Libya's largest oil port, Es-Sider, is on the cusp of restarting loadings, which would lift the most important hurdle standing in the way of a return to normal exports following the end of the civil war, the country's oil chief said.

headline: India in Pictures: 2011
summary: Photo highlights of the year in India.

headline: India Shares Post First Annual Fall in 3 Years
summary: Indian shares finished in the red, bringing to an end a season--and year--which has been far from festive for investors.

headline: Fosun Surprised By Soho China Shanghai Investment
summary: A fight is brewing between two of China's biggest property developers as they wrestle for control of a commercial real-estate site in the heart of Shanghai.

headline: India in Pictures
summary: A fire breather at a religious procession, a boy plays on a beach in Chennai, Mahendra Singh Dhoni gets bowled at the Melbourne Cricket Ground, and more.

headline: IMF Warned Greece on Debt Levels
summary: The International Monetary Fund recently told the Greek government that a worsening economic outlook suggests the beleaguered nation may be unable to reduce its debt to sustainable levels even with a planned 50% write down in privately-held Greek government bonds.

headline: Hua Hong, Grace to Merge
summary: Hua Hong Semiconductor and Grace Semiconductor Manufacturing agreed to merge in a move that highlights consolidation in China's fragmented semiconductor industry.

headline: Flawed Miracle: The WSJ's India Series
summary: The Wall Street Journal's South Asia bureau spent 2011 chronicling how India is in danger of squandering the huge potential unleashed by historic reforms 20 years ago.

headline: Knicks Flawed in Loss to Lakers
summary: When the Knicks signed center Tyson Chandler the gamble was clear: stack three stars on top of a dozen extras and see what happens. So far, it's not playing out too well.

headline: Borrowing From ECB Jumps
summary: Euro-zone banks' overnight borrowing from the European Central Bank jumped to a level unseen since early this year, while their deposits remained close to the record levels hit earlier this week.

headline: Cyclone Thane Hits Tamil Nadu
summary: A severe cyclone hit coastal parts of India's southern Tamil Nadu state, threatening standing crops of rice, groundnut and corn, the country's weather department said.

headline: Entertainment in India: 2011
summary: From a Bollywood movie about a pornstar to Indian composers jamming with international artists, to canceled music concerts and first-time visits of Hollywood celebrities, 2011 was a colorful year for entertainment in India. In pictures.

headline: World Watch
summary: World Watch

headline: Tea-Party Ties Little Help to Gingrich
summary: Before entering the presidential race, Gingrich traveled the country to build alliances with tea-party activists and train them to run for office, including those in key primary states. But that effort doesn't appear to be paying off.

headline: North Korea Wraps Up Tribute
summary: North Korea managed one more visual wallop as it said its last goodbye to dictator Kim Jong Il—a tableau of tens, perhaps hundreds, of thousands of people standing in its capital to hear a final homage.

headline: Anticorruption Bill Fails in India
summary: India failed to get crucial legislation through Parliament in an emotive late-night session, adding to the policy paralysis of Prime Minister Singh's government.

headline: High Yields Leave Italy's Hands Tied
summary: Italy's funding costs eased from the euro-era high levels seen at the previous tender a month ago, benefiting from improved confidence in the past few sessions.

headline: Lawmakers Lose in Markets
summary: Some members of Congress took losses trading stocks and committed basic investing mistakes, according to a Wall Street Journal analysis of financial disclosures.

headline: New Year's Eve Shows
summary: A sampling of New Year's Eve shows from around the country.

headline: Strassel: Newt's Economic Stand
summary: Voters seem to like his pro-growth message but still have doubts about the messenger.

headline: Seeking a Golden Glow, Some Rush to the Spa
summary: The focus on gold has a new twist in Thailand, where demand has grown for facial treatments that involve massaging gold particles into the skin in an effort to draw out toxins and create the impression of a healthy glow.

headline: I Say Soccer Is Better Than Football
summary: Without wanting to cause pain to my American friends, I prefer to describe American football as 5% action and 95% standing around waiting for commercials.

headline: Iran to File in U.S. Court to Unfreeze Funds
summary: Iran's central bank is preparing to file a motion in a New York federal court early next year to release nearly $2 billion of its frozen funds at Citigroup Inc.'s Citibank unit, according to attorneys for the Iranian bank.

headline: A Voice of the East, Heard From the West
summary: Indian-born novelist Anita Desai speaks with the Journal in her Cold Springs, N.Y., home about her new triptych of novellas, 'The Artist of Disappearance.'

headline: Drywalling for a Better New York
summary: David Terveen volunteers with the New York City affiliate of Habitat for Humanity, the international nonprofit that builds homes with the participation of homeowners and volunteers. He also recently donated $600,000 to the organization.

headline: Japan Inc.'s Appetite for Deals
summary: A bumper year for Japanese-led mergers and acquisition activity is reason to cheer for those who advise on such deals. For investors there's less to celebrate.

headline: Riverside South Sees Burst of Sales
summary: After years at the center of a battle between real-estate titans and community groups, condo sales at Riverside South, on the fringes of the Upper West Side, appear to have rebounded.

headline: In an African Dynamo's Expansion, the Perils of Prosperity
summary: Ghana is Africa's fastest-growing nation, and No. 2 in the world. But infrastructure bottlenecks are curbing what economists say could be even faster growth, offering lessons for other African countries that may follow a similar path of development.

headline: Tensions Rise Over Drone Secrecy
summary: Tensions are quietly increasing between the White House and some congressional leaders over access to sensitive information about the government's use of drones in Pakistan and Yemen, officials said.

headline: Drug Falls Short In Cancer Study
summary: Roche's Avastin failed to lengthen ovarian cancer patients' lives but stalled progression of the disease for a few months in studies reported in the New England Journal of Medicine.

headline: A City Slips as Downgrade Hits Home
summary: Long a model American community with high-performing schools, beautiful parks and rising real estate values, University Place, on the Puget Sound, has turned into a reluctant showcase for the downgrading of America.

headline: A 'King' That Is Full of Aces
summary: Great musicals can profit from up-to-date dictorial thinking, but traditional stagings are no less satisfying when they're executed stylishly and with gusto, which is what happens with the Walnut Street Theatre's "The King and I."

headline: When Coaches Face Their Alma Maters
summary: How do coaches fare when they go up against their old school?

headline: Tech Flops of the Year
summary: The tech flops of the year included the BlackBerry PlayBook, a Color Labs mobile app and Solyndra.

headline: Rolling With the Rhythms
summary: Our New Year's Eve edition of the jazz calendar leads off with Wynton Marsalis's tribute to Jelly Roll Morton and King Oliver at Dizzy's, and moves on to Eric Alexander and Harold Mabern at Smoke, the Bad Plus at the Vanguard, and Marilyn Maye at the Metropolitan Room.

headline: Tax Offices in Greece Are Closed Amid Strike
summary: Greek tax officials began a 48-hour walkout to protest wage cuts and other changes imposed by the government as Greece struggles to meet revenue targets it has promised international creditors.

headline: Ron Paul Says U.S. Should Have Anticipated Hatred
summary: Contrary to what Dorothy Rabinowitz says in her commentary, Ron Paul does not say that Americans deserve to be hated and attacked.

headline: The Year's Best Sports Images
summary: The photographers behind some of 2011's most iconic sports images discuss how they were captured.

headline: Stop the Presses: U.S. Printer Bails
summary: The Obama administration's confirmation troubles have come to this: It can't get the Senate to accept its nominee for public printer of the United States.

headline: Going to the Bronx—Not the Beach
summary: Price and weather make a bowl game in New York City less than ideal for fans of Iowa State.

headline: Miller and Hillman: How to Get More Ivy Leaguers Into ROTC
summary: While the bans on the military are mostly gone, the Pentagon needs to loosen its purse strings.

headline: Walgreen Cuts Costs as Key Pact Ends
summary: Walgreen has begun a plan to cut costs to help protect profits in anticipation of client losses stemming from the failure to renew a contract with Express Scripts.

headline: U.S. to Sell F-15s to Saudi Arabia
summary: The Obama administration said it has reached a $30 billion agreement to sell advanced fighter aircraft to Saudi Arabia, part of a broader push by Washington to counter Iranian power.

headline: Web Sales Sparkled
summary: Web sales between Nov. 1 and Dec. 26 totaled $35.3 billion, up 15% from a year earlier, greatly outpacing the 3.8% gain for sales overall. A greater portion came from mobile devices, too.

headline: Verizon Outages, $2 Fee Irk Customers
summary: Verizon is planning a $2 fee for customers paying bills by phone and online. The company also said its engineers fixed the month's third outage of its 4G network.

headline: Ideas Calendar: Dec. 31-Jan. 6
summary: On the agenda: Stephen Hawking's 70th birthday, English professors meet and a lecture on the origins of carnival holidays.

headline: Walter Russell Mead: America's Play for Pacific Prosperity
summary: The U.S. has quietly set up a bipartisan Asia policy that may be as influential as the Marshall Plan and NATO.

headline: New Stimulus Dovetails With Shift at Fed
summary: One of the biggest questions looming for 2012 is whether the central bank will pursue more extraordinary measures to ease monetary policy. A shift in the board's voting ranks suggests the tone is getting dovish.

headline: Paradise Lost
summary: Long a model American community with high-performing schools, beautiful parks and rising real estate values, University Place, Wash., has lately turned into a reluctant showcase for the downgrading of America.

headline: Sunday May Determine Schottenheimer's Fate
summary: The coach has long drawn the ire of some Jets' fans, and now —with the team coming off a ghastly offensive performance and in danger of missing the playoffs for the first time three years—could be in danger of losing his job once New York's season concludes.

headline: Calif. Redevelopment Entities Hit
summary: Local agencies charged with renewing blighted neighborhoods in California soon could be abolished after a state court ruling Thursday.

headline: Jenny Craig Sells Home for $6.1 Million
summary: Jenny Craig sells a home to her daughter and son-in-law, while Kleiner Perkins's Byers drops a San Francisco price by 20%.

headline: NFL Week 17: The Massey-Peabody Power Rankings
summary: The Jets have fallen all the way to 13th—one slot behind their Week 17 opponent, Miami, which is predicted to win by 2.48 points.

headline: Donor Criticism Was a Misunderstanding
summary: In the days after Deloris Gillespie was burned to death in the elevator of her Prospect Heights apartment, the horrific story caught the eye of businessman Darren Weingrow.

headline: Umenyiora Doesn't Want to Get in Way of JPP
summary: 'He deserves to be the starter, there's no question about it,' said a now healthy Osi Umenyiora of Jason Pierre-Paul; elsewhere the Rangers ratings are up and LaDainian Tomlinson says Sunday Mmy be his last game.

headline: Dubstep as the New Rock
summary: The dubstep craze has taken on a life of its own: Musicians from Katy Perry to Korn are throwing around the term to describe their new releases --  and dubstep music producer Skrillex recently became the first disc jockey to ever be nominated for a Best New Artist Grammy.

headline: Hungarian Doctors Seek Higher Pay
summary: More than 2,500 Hungarian doctors have said they are set to quit their jobs on Jan. 1 if they aren't granted higher salaries.

headline: Santorum's Surge . . .
summary: Rick Santorum has rocketed to third place in Iowa, according to the most recent CNN/Time poll.

headline: Romney Plans Late Push in Iowa
summary: Mitt Romney signaled increasing confidence he will finish strongly in Iowa's Republican presidential contest, scheduling more time in the state ahead of Tuesday's caucuses.

headline: The Freedom Writer
summary: Writings on Tibet, Tiananmen Square and Chinese society by Liu Xiaobo, the imprisoned dissident who won the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize.

headline: If Only Every Quarter Were Like the Fourth
summary: The Giants have mounted six comebacks in the final stanza--the same period where Dallas has lost five games.

headline: Italian Bond Risk Keeps Bubbling Away
summary: Auctions this week of Italian government debt have offered a mixed picture of where Europe's debt crisis stands going into the New Year.

headline: Biggest Tech Innovations of 2011
summary: The iPhone and Facebook may have dominated headlines, but many other firms flexed their creative muscles, with inventions ranging from brainy computers to self-piloting planes.

headline: Winery Living in Napa Valley
summary: This 300-acre property in California's Napa Valley includes a 16,000-square-foot winery with the same limestone siding and French red-clay roof tiles featured on the 3,000-square-foot house. Between the two buildings are 12 acres of grapes used to make Cabernet Sauvignon and Sauvignon Blanc.

headline: Serial Garage Sales Prompt Crackdowns
summary: Municipalities across the U.S. are trying to curb recurring garage sales, which officials say often disrupt neighborhoods, cheat governments out of sales tax and pose unfair competition to retailers.

headline: A Mere $110 Million
summary: It may be the most expensive home listing ever in Manhattan: $110 million  for a glass-walled penthouse overlooking Central Park on top of what will soon be the borough's tallest residential building.

headline: Court Frees Up Hurd Letter
summary: A letter off events leading to Mark Hurd's resignation as H-P's chief executive describes an "uncomfortable dance that went on almost two years," alleging that his unwanted advances put a female contractor in the difficult position of rejecting her boss while trying to preserve her job.

headline: Homes for the Holidays
summary: Dyker Heights, an Italian stronghold of generously sized houses, has held on to a tradition that began more than 25 years ago, before the demographics of many of the surrounding neighborhoods began to shift.

headline: Japan's SMFG Eyeing Deals
summary: Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group hopes to take advantage of Japan Inc.'s growing appetite for global deals, with a range of services including financing, capital-raising and advising on mergers and acquisitions.

headline: Shirin Ebadi: Behind the Islamic Republic's Bluster
summary: The regime's rants about closing the Strait of Hormuz divert the world's attention from the thousands of political prisoners in its jails.

headline: City Requests Casual Eatery at Tavern Site
summary: The city put out a long-awaited call for a new operator for the shuttered Tavern on the Green restaurant on Thursday, which will transform what was once a fine-dining cash cow into a casual eatery with a significantly reduced footprint.

headline: Noonan: Gingrich Is Making Romney Better
summary: The most memorable campaign line so far isn't '9-9-9' or 'Oops.'

headline: Commodities Decline After Strong Start
summary: The past year was dotted by records across commodities markets, as investors piled into the sector chasing higher returns. But gains vanished in highflying markets.

headline: Sarkozy Outlines Jobs Plan
summary: Sarkozy's government is using the holiday break to arrange a plan aimed at containing a sharp rise in unemployment by persuading companies and workers to agree to a new deal: pay cuts for job guarantees.

headline: An Oceanfront Estate in Maine
summary: This 5,800-square-foot English Cotswold-style home outside Portland was built in 1928 and sits on more than 14 acres on the Atlantic coast.

headline: All the President's Detainees
summary: What do you know, a consensus emerges on antiterror policy.

headline: New Look at Pipeline Blasts
summary: Regulators are increasingly focusing on how flaws in, or stresses on, a pipeline that appear minor on their own can exacerbate each other, magnifying the risk of rupture.

headline: Connecticut Graduation Rate Edges Upward
summary: Connecticut Gov. Dan Malloy's administration on Thursday came out with a mixed bag of news about the graduation rates of the state's public-school students: More are graduating on time, but the demographic gaps are as wide as ever.

headline: Allison Pond: From American Idol to Mormon Missionary
summary: A pop star trades the stage for Bible-teaching sessions in a distant land.

headline: Deutsche Telekom Settles Charges
summary: Deutsche Telekom and its Hungarian telecom unit will pay about $95 million in penalties to resolve U.S. probes over alleged bribes by former executives to government officials in Macedonia and Montenegro.

headline: Surf Swami Knew When to Hang Ten
summary: Sean Collins transformed the search for a perfect wave from a spiritual quest to something like a science.

headline: Holder's Racial Politics
summary: The AG's attack on voter ID laws may backfire legally and politically.

headline: TV on DVD
summary: "Justified," "Alfred Hitchcock Presents" and HBO's "Mildred Pierce."

headline: Stay Constant, Mr. Romney, and Beware Demagogues
summary: I love Mr. Romney's vision "to return America to the principles that we were founded upon . . . I hope he relentlessly hammers that theme and continually contrasts his vision with that of Mr. Obama.

headline: Europe's Leaders May Need History Lesson
summary: Given their record to date, is there any reason for faith that Europe's leaders will succeed in 2012 in doing what they signally failed to do in 2011 and stem the crisis that now threatens the existence of the euro zone?

headline: That's Not a Louis Vuitton
summary: Lawsuits over trademark infringement are fast growing frivolous and ubiquitous.

headline: An Estate on the Ocean
summary: Built in 1928, this English Cotswold-style home in a suburb south of Portland sits on more than 14 acres on the Atlantic coast.

summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Asia.

headline: California Low-Carbon Rules Halted
summary: In a victory for refiners and ethanol producers, a federal judge halted enforcement of California's low-carbon fuel rules, saying they discriminated against crude oil and ethanol imported into the state.

headline: In 2012, I'm Getting My Hopes Up
summary: Joe Queenan, in his Moving Targets column, looks at the "glass-half-empty" habit of experts.

headline: Friendly's to Stay With Sun Capital
summary: Sun Capital Partners got the nod Thursday from a judge to pilot its Friendly Ice Cream out of bankruptcy on a course that will resolve many of the restaurant chain's financial troubles.

headline: Resolved: Less Stuff, Less Me
summary: Our housing columnist reveals her plans to slim down both her stuff and herself in the New Year.

headline: Fast Food in the Financial District
summary: Take heed, New Yorkers: A Midwestern sandwich chain is infiltrating Manhattan. Potbelly Sandwich Shop, known for its inexpensive but tasty subs, just added its fifth outpost in the last six months.

headline: New Brazil Boom: Collecting Debts
summary: As the volume of loans has increased in Brazil, so, too, have bad loans. That has meant plenty of new opportunities for debt collection.

headline: Rescuing Movie Season
summary: "Mission Impossible—Ghost Protocol," is accomplishing a similarly impossible feat: saving the movie business from a year-end slump.

headline: Computer Sciences Narrows CEO Hunt
summary: Computer Sciences, potentially facing a financial hit from a troubled U.K. contract, has assembled a list of front-runners to replace its current chief executive and hopes to pick an outsider for the job early in 2012.

headline: United Mechanics Ratify Pact
summary: In a rare piece of good news amid protracted labor negotiations at United Airlines, mechanics represented by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters overwhelmingly ratified a new labor agreement.

headline: Turkey Strike Fires Kurdish Tensions
summary: Turkish warplanes killed 35 villagers in an airstrike targeting Kurdish rebels on the Iraqi border, sparking riots and raising tensions with the restive minority at a time of heightened assertiveness by Kurds in neighboring nations.

headline: Banks Face Off For Facebook IPO
summary: Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley are the front-runners for the prestigious and lucrative job of leading Facebook's IPO. Still, other investment banks aren't giving up.

headline: Egyptian Raids on U.S. Groups Draw Ire
summary: Egyptian soldiers and police stormed nongovernmental organization offices, adding tensions to fraying ties between Egypt's interim military leadership and its allies in Washington.

headline: Iowa's Evangelical Rift Could Curb Influence
summary: The crucial evangelical vote in Iowa is fractured and uncertain just days before the first ballots will be cast in the Republican presidential race, potentially boosting Mitt Romney.

headline: Philippine Guerrillas Seize on Flood Issue
summary: The flash floods that killed more than 1,200 in the southern Philippines are providing Asia's longest-running Communist insurgency an opportunity to reinvent itself as a steward for the country's badly depleted environment.

headline: Private Properties
summary: Weight-loss guru Jenny Craig sells her home near San Diego for $6.1 million. Also, venture capitalist Brook Byers and his wife cut the price on their San Francisco home by 20%, and former music executive Charles Goldstuck asks $18.8 million for his Connecticut mansion.

headline: A Guide to the Knicks' Silly Season
summary: In a highly compact season, chemistry and health may mean more than wins and losses.

headline: Arts Center at WTC Takes Step Forward
summary: A board of directors was named Thursday for a Frank Gehry-designed performing-arts center planned for the World Trade Center site, two days shy of a deadline for the venue to remain eligible for $100 million in funding.

headline: All About Yveses
summary: HBO's "Angry Boys" and ABC's "Work It" both explore the challenges of contemporary manhood for laughs, but only one is family viewing.

headline: Sears Details Closures
summary: Sears Holdings identified 79 of the stores the retailer is planning to close, with nearly half being Kmart locations and Florida having the most closures by state.

headline: Boeing Examines Supply Chain
summary: Boeing's production struggles with its 787 Dreamliner taught it to regularly stress-test suppliers, a skill that is now coming to the forefront as it tackles a mountain of orders for its best-selling 737 jets.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: D.A. Cracks Down On Internet Crime
summary: In a remote corner of a dimly lit Lower Manhattan government building, analysts at high-tech workstations spend their days scouring smartphones, iPads and laptops for evidence of criminal activity. The lab is part of an effort to combat cybercrime by Manhattan District Attorney Cyrus R. Vance.

headline: Don Cheadle on 'House of Lies'
summary: He plays a cutthroat management consultant whose professional morals are as nebulous as his job description

headline: Taliban Attacks Kill 13, Reflect Shift
summary: Ten members of a British-trained Afghan force were killed by a roadside bomb in the south of the country, and an Afghan soldier in the east killed another soldier and two French sergeants, nearing the end of a year marked by violence that reflected a shift in insurgent strategy.

headline: Data Suggest Recovery Gaining Steam
summary: Fewer Americans are filing new claims for jobless benefits than at any time since the end of the recession, the latest signal that the U.S. economy is ending a year of uncertainty on a positive note.

headline: Do Good Fences Make Good Bankers?
summary: Aligning the politics and the economics of bank bailouts in the post-panic world.

headline: L.A. Nights: Bret Easton Ellis at the Movies
summary: When it comes to opinions about movies, on his Twitter account, the novelist Bret Easton Ellis has become an unwavering, occasionally provocative, often curmudgeonly and extremely funny voice, shuffling between the high brow and the low.

headline: In Napa, Blending a House and Winery
summary: A complex looks like it's been in Provence forever—with a bag of tricks to keep maintenance down.

headline: A Margin for Error in Hedge-Fund Filings
summary: Are some of the smart-money crowd playing investors for suckers? A new analysis raises more questions about the reported returns of a large universe of hedge funds.
